Award.AwardTitle: Marine Geoscience Leadership Symposium: Professional Development for Early Career Researchers
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal seeks funds to organize the third and fourth Marine Geoscience Leadership Symposia , following symposia run in 2009 and 2011. These are 5-day events held in Washington. The aim is to provide leadership skills to a cohort of 25 early career scientists capable of participating in collaborative research and science planning. The symposium will include formal presentations, group discussions, and mentoring. The goal is to increase the effectiveness of early career scientists as they enter the marine geosciences community, not only in the classroom and laboratory, but also as leaders in the broader effort to increase geoscience literacy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Marine Geoscience Leadership Symposium (MGLS, NSF Standard Grant OCE-1235507), managed by the Consortium for Ocean Leadership, was a professional development program that provided leadership and communications training, as well as mentoring and network- and cohort-building opportunities, to early career marine geoscientists entering academia. Two symposia were held in 2013 and 2015, and 48 early career marine geoscientists participated. This was a renewal of a previous award to Ocean Leadership to manage the Marine Geoscience Leadership Symposium; the first two symposia took place in 2009 and 2011. The MGLS program had six goals: (1) grow and develop effective leadership qualities, (2) improve skills in communicating scientific research and results, (3) identify and discuss areas of research that benefit from an interdisciplinary approach, (4) provide training in writing effective grant proposals, (5) provide a broader perspective on science policy and science funding, and (6) develop long-lasting collaborative relationships among a cohort of early career scientists. Through mentoring (peer-to-peer and with senior geoscientists) and training in skills that extend beyond the classroom and laboratory, the early career researchers who participated in this symposium gained expertise to support them as leaders and successful representatives of the scientific community in the years to come.

MGLS participants were selected to participate in each of the two week-long symposia through a competitive application process. Twenty-four applicants were selected for each of the symposia in 2013 and 2015. Applicants were recruited from all subfields of marine geology and marine geophysics and were required to have received their Ph.D. within the three years preceding their participation. A steering committee composed of Ocean Leadership program staff, leaders in the marine geosciences field, and former MGLS participants developed the agendas and objectives for each symposium. In addition, two mentors participated in each symposium, moderating panels and providing guidance and advice to attendees throughout the week. The MGLS symposia included communications and science policy training, training on interdisciplinary leadership and working effectively on teams, proposal writing training, and meetings with National Science Foundation Program Managers in which participants learned about the proposal review process and were given advice on writing successful proposals. Each symposium also included a group project, which participants worked on throughout the week and presented to a panel on the final day for feedback. In 2017, Ocean Leadership hosted a series of three webinars focused on topics identified by MGLS alumni as ongoing challenges, including mentoring, strategic time management, and proposal writing.

Participants were surveyed at the end of each symposium to gather their feedback on their experiences and improve on the program. In 2016, the College of Exploration and Ashland University surveyed the 97 past participants (across all relevant funding awards) on their experiences participating in MGLS. Fifty-one past participants completed the survey. Many respondents said they regularly used skills they acquired through participating in the program and relationships they had built during the symposium had directly led to successful collaborations and NSF funding.

For more information on the MGLS program, please visit: http://oceanleadership.org/education/mgls/.
